I work in renewable energy. Cutting edge renewable energy technology has its own eco-tourist visitor, a sector I would like to see grow on Cape Cod. In addition to an increase in the numbers of tourists coming to witness Cape Cod's cutting edge RE technologies, my contributions to the Cape's economic health will continue as I bring forward no-cost renewables to the municipalities through the work of the Cape & Vineyard Electric Cooperative.

I envision the Cape becoming an Eco-model that could draw grant monies from the federal sector (not that any exist due to the budget overdraw), tourist dollars, and scientific funding. The three "toppings" that would be key to the success to a flourishing economy from green technology and exemplary life-style modeling are: Arts, Recreation & Entertainment, Agriculture, Forestry & Hunting, and Utilities. I believe the Cape offers all the pieces of the puzzle and opportunities to become a model in renewable energy, home-grown foods, fossil-fuel free transportation, smart growth, etc. Tourists would visit the Cape in greater numbers to enjoy not only the clean beaches and waters, but also to participate in a lifestyle that is entirely green, if even for a weekend holiday.

Eel Grass\nWithout the eelgrass, the others in the list would be negatively impacted. The crabs hide and feed in the eelgrass.  Little organisms that feed the oysters grown in the eelgrass.  The cod, scallops, sea birds and bluefish rely on the little fish and organisms that grow and live in the eelgrass. I would be effected because without the full cycle ecology benefits from the eelgrass, I would no longer have seafoood or healthy waters.

I used to visit the marsh in Orleans Town Cove to observe the little things like fish and mussels growing and living in the eelgrass by the shore. But now, after years of people flushing toilets, using fertilizer and after construction along the shore with things like backhoes, my little observable friends, like the fish and the mussels, have disappeared along with the eelgrass.  I'm not discouraged, though, because my friends the oysters are rallying to help by taking out the excess nutrients, which will bring back the eelgrass, and then my little fish and mussel friends will return so I can again go visit them in Town Cove..

My super hero would tackle the septic tank problem. It's powers would be the ability to convert septic tanks to sewer systems to reduce the amount of nitrogen going into the water.

He could tell them about how wastewater effects organisms in water. Wastewater adds nitrogen to the water, and this causes algae to bloom. This takes sunlight away from plants in the bottom, and it also makes the fish compete with the algae for nutrients. This could help them to decide that the wastewater plan is the best course of action.

If my contribution went to a fund dedicated to wastewater solutions only, If the state and federal government helped\nMy self interest tells me to check I'd like to pay on how much wastewater I generate, but I can't choose that one. Thinking of the property owners of the house I visit: They don't create a lot of waste - they're not there for much of the year. They rent out sometimes and sometimes I come to visit. Is the waste generated by their renters and visitors considered to be their waste? If not, who is going to pay for my visiting behind's waste? If it's me (the visitor), we're back to a swipe to wipe system of pay toilets everywhere I go on Cape.  State & Federal money should be part of this as the Cape is home to the National Seashore - the main draw to the lodging and eating and retail establishments. I don't know that having everyone contribute equally is right, as not all waste producers contribute the equal amounts. There has to be a combined assessment of costs.

Other (tell us)\nThis is wide open for Mass residents to jump in and correct this out of state visitor's incorrect assumptions and ignorance on how commonwealth politics really work.  Since watersheds cross town borders and town borders cross watersheds, it would be difficult to address the issues on a scale of either town or watershed alone. If a watershed group comes up with a proposal to be voted on, do only the people in the watershed get to vote? If a proposal requires spending, a watershed group can't levy taxes like a town can. Likewise, town on their own can't regulate all the residents of a watershed if some are in the town next door.  As far as working groups, I think it should start out at the watershed level with representatives from the towns as well as other stakeholders.This can all be done under the umbrella of the county, which does may have some authority over all Cape residents. Watershed districts can be set up under county oversight..
Nauset.The photo is of a cranberry bog not in use in the Nauset watershed.

It looks like it's still functional as far as the piping - I just haven't seen anybody using it. I have seen various kinds of ducks and a muskrat. A family member saw a coyote walking around the edge one morning. It's a bit of a wildlife corridor/watering hole near (but no next to) the rail trail with a somewhat "main" road in the front and wooded backyards behind.

response: Buy properties with future potential, Allow development rights in remote areas to be transferred to areas where wastewater infrastructure is present, Allow more development, but only where it currently exists\nA variety of approaches is necessary. By concentrating growth in areas that are already developed, it makes it easier to address problems due to economy of scale for projects such as wastewater treatment.

Yes\nThe nutrient loadings come from a multitude of point and non-point sources. Centralized wastewater treatment facilities with collections systems are expensive to construct and maintain. The larger they are, the more expensive they are. Siting them is difficult in such varied terrain as is found on :Cape - especially given the amount of wetlands and sensitive or protected recreational areas. Also, the level of treatment to remove nutrients is higher than traditional sewage plants - to any plant built will be a higher level than they used to be in the past - which means more cost as well, The need for such systems can be decreased if the on-site systems are made more efficient in the removal of nutrients. If systems are "upgraded" when a replacement is needed anyway, it reduces the burden to homeowners than would be placed if a requirement to upgrade a system that "works perfectly fine".

Installation for free, Free removal of collected urine\nI chose these two because I am thinking that is what it would take for the people who own the house I visit.  They will not want to pay to change the infrastructure in their house and I'd guess they wouldn't want to change anything anyway - but I think if installation was free and collection was free AND they thought it could minimize the enormous costs of addressing the Cape-wide water quality issues (they fear they will be priced out of their second home and have to leave the Cape) they would be more likely to consider it.  All new homes absolutely should start out with the most efficient and least load producing fixtures.  Also expansions (added bathrooms) and renovations over a certain percentage of the structure should require retrofit or meet new requirements for the new portions.

Other (Tell us)\nI'd need more information. The bottom line has to be getting the job done. I know constructed wetlands do work. I mainly know them in the context of a "hard" treatment system (a wastewater treatment facility plant), so I'd want to know more about whether they are being used in areas with septic systems rather than point source plants. Years ago, "natural" systems were treated as "let them be natural" systems once they were built.  You can't create it and forget about it - they do need attending to. They have open space and wildlife benefits. There really has to be a cost benefit analysis and a comparison to costs of sewage treatment plants.  There may be locations where a combination approach would be needed. I think if you can get a natural system cited appropriately and take care to really put in the effort at the start, it just may prove to cost less (chemicals, machinery manpower) and work better.
replies: I meant "sited", not "cited". At my office we talk about siting facilities, we cite regulations and talk about  citations for non-compliance. I my hands typed out the wrong one.

response: Form a formal association of towns with counties holding a seat too.

Acquire adequate land for future wastewater treatment facilities (which may include a sewage treatment plant and/or biological treatment systems such as created wetlands designed with specific effluent parameters in mind. Site these facilities in the most hydrogeologically appropriate locations around the Cape. Include right of way easements for future collection system pipes. In areas not appropriate for offsite sewage treament, require waterless toilets and low flow fixtures and appliances. Consider hold and haul facilities for sensitive areas if development can't be avoided.  Impose deed restrictions on establishment of fertilizer dependent lawns. Use zoning to establish land most appropriate for various activities based on their anticipated nitrogen load, and only allow variances when the landowner proposes an enforceable waste load reduction plan and mitigation plan. Allow for more dense development in areas that are less sensitive, but collect fees for the privilege that will be banked by the municipality to address future needs in relation to wastewater nutrient load reduction.  Invest in research of new land-based buffers or physical barriers to reduce agricultural runoff with high nutrient loads.

Our superhero would tackle the nitrogen coming from wastewater. He has the power of a team of data collecting followers who collect quality data about the current state of all of the waterbodies in each watershed behind him. He has a robust modeling program that has taken into account the waste loads from each source, the permeability of the soil metereological data, demographic data related to land use. He has the power of persuasion with which he convinces the people that action must be taken. He has the power of flexibility, which he uses to design custom approaches to each property in the drainage basin.

Ouch. Ideally, he can educate the voters on what he has learned and open a discussion that ends in voters coming to a decision on how to fund - even if it means raising taxes. People don't like the feeling of being lied to or having promises broken; but people can be reasonable when there is transparency and they feel they have some choices.  Jim will need to show a cost benefit analysis, as well as a comparison of the costs of the options: no action, partial action, the gold star option.  He will need to apply some environmental economics to the issue and broaden the picture. Environmental quality needs to be a factor in the discussion; the focus can't be just on financial cost. Cradle to grave timeframes must be used to provide people a better way to judge whether they will support the changes he wants to make. This means the discussion must include factors such as maintenance and individual costs to taxpayers and bonding or grants.

Other (tell us)\nThere should be a demand component as part of an income discount. If someone is creating a certain percent more than an "average" demand or has a considerably lower footprint, discounts or surcharges could be used.

It's tough.  There may be day visitors.  Pay toilets are tough - I saw one on Martha's Vineyard - the first person paid and the whole line after that just grabbed the door before it closed, so that place probably couldn't even pay for it's own toilet paper after that. You can't differentiate between residents and visitors unless you get a swipe card - swipe to flush!. Plus - is a resident of Sandwich a "visitor" when in Provincetown on the 4th of July? Is a resident of Eastham a "visitor" when at the National Seashore Visitor's Center?  The lodging owners are really the "users" in a large way. Towns regulate how many guests you can rent to, based on your septic, don't they?  Is there a situation where owners routinely rent to larger groups in violation of their certificate, or permit, or whatever they need? if you are only going to charge visitors, then do residents have to wait until they get home to use the bathroom?  I would like to see a massive overhaul in the public restroom situation.  What about providing adequate numbers of "free" waterless toilets in high pedestrian traffic areas while perhaps putting a surcharge on public bathrooms in non-upgraded establishments? I'm just brainstorming, but the idea is to reroute tourists to facilities with minimal loading to the waterways. Perhaps a business that installs one such system can get some credit or relief from a "flush" tax.  If a wastewater surcharge is on the horizon for lodging establishments, perhaps it could be tiered based on the loadings produced per visitor - to reward places that upgrade or go to waterless toilets.

Expansion of Bottle Bill, State or Federal Grants, Gaming Proceeds\nThe theory of a bottle bill was to divert bottles from landfills; and environmental basis. Using the non-returned bottle windfall for environmental purposes would be in line with that. Going for state or federal grants is reasonable since the state benefits from taxes paid by tourists for retail purchases made on vacation, and people come to see the beauty of the National Seashore. If a state is allowing or promoting gaming as a fundraiser, this makes sense as well to use it for something that benefits the protection of natural resources and fisheries of the state,
replies: You make a great point regarding the bottle bill. And if it was on water bottles too it might eliminate some use of them and/or plastic waste often found floating in the water.\\  In 1982 non-carbonated drinks made up a small fraction of the beverage market; but now represents more than 23 percent of the market .NY's recently expanded bottle bill program now includes: carbonated soda/water, energy drinks, juice (must have added water or sugar), malt beverages, mineral water, wine and water (no suger). 80% of the windfall must be turned over to Tax & Finance.

response: I buy local wherever I am if possible.  I am willing to pay more to a farmer if we've met and have  chat about the farm because I want to support that type of land use as "open space".  I will only shop a "big box" when I can't get a product from a local independent retailer, even if it costs more.  Though I don't live on Cape, I visit when I can.  I have found the service industry to be so very customer friendly - I will bring my bike from home for service; I will hold on to broken jewelry to have it fixed on the Cape and wait to buy certain books there.  I think the feeling that one belongs, even when one doesn't live there is a huge selling point. When I see my favorite clam shack operator somewhere else on the Cape, like a hardware store or a gas station, they've given me a nod in recognition. So many people in the service industry (not necessarily the imported help; but the owners) have an AMAZING capacity to remember people and make them feel like they are neighbors even in the face of thousands of transient visitors. Now that I am aware of the food producers shown in the resources, I will make an effort to buy from them (many of them I have already visited - and "pinned" links to them on my Cape Cod Pinterest page).

Retail, healthcare and hospitality (food, lodging) are the top three job areas on the Cape.  People come to the Cape for nature and water based activities. They need lodging and they eat. I'll take an idea and run with it here:  If most of the people who live on the Cape have footprints the size of many of the participants in this game claim to have (significantly smaller than the national average!), I'd guess that they are not eating as much as the visitors!  Therefore, tourists who are renting lodging and are eating out (a lot) really drives the economy.  They are also shopping when they come. If wastewater disposal becomes the limiting factor, those tourists won't be able to come.  Worse, if the nutrients in the wastewater ruin the very resources the tourists come to see, they won't stick around too long to drive the healthcare economy any more either - they won't be visiting Hyannis Hospital to have a seashell removed from their foot, or a jellyfish sting tended to or a finger stitched up from a nasty cut from a wire leader attached to a big striped bass.

Since so much of the land is in areas where travel time is less than ten years, it's possible to see great improvement in that "short" time., while keeping in mind that contributors to poor water quality will still be seeping down to the water from the areas with a longer travel time.

My footprint is 96 pounds per year. I do not live on the Cape (a family member has a house & I visit as much as possible). One area I know I could reduce my footprint; however, would be to get a more efficient vehicle. If I did live on the Cape, I know I would have a smaller house than the one I live in, and I would not have a pool like I do now, so gas/electric would be less. I don't know how to compare heating fuel oil to the piped-in natural gas I currently use. Any house on the cape would be better insulated than my current home, so I would use less energy. I would bike more; there are few safe bike routes where I live now. I would eat less beef and more fish, but I don't know what that would do to my footprint.

The trophic index for phosphorus at the upper levels of the water column have remained relatively stable for the five year period with that level being either mesotrophic or eutrophic at times.  The lower levels of the water column has trended toward hypereutrophic and the last sample exceeded 300 mg/l with was lextremely higher than the previous samples, which were in the range of 75-100 mg/l.  I would wonder if there was an overuse of fertilizer immediately before a torrential rainstorm, or perhaps a septic system failed. Should this trend continue, the upper levels of the pond may also experience an increase in the trophic index values.

[[[41.81956620179798, -69.96280875554197]]]\nI enjoy the open space on the Fort Hill trails. They are protected as part of the National Seashore. They provide habitat for birds and mammals as well as recreational space. The space, near a marsh and open waterways, provides some buffer from runoff from developed areas.

Wetlands Protection, Bacteria Contamination, Stormwater Runoff\nTough choices. My choices are not to suggest that drinking water is not important as it is critical for all residents and visitors. This is an acute problem for people living over currently a contaminated supply BUT, hear me out. Shellfishing is an economic resource dependent on bacteria-free product. If we address bacteria contamination, that will also benefit private wells impacted by septic. Stormwater runoff impacts shellfish areas and swimming areas. If we approach stormwater issues by addressing the elements in the stormwater, that will protect the waterways and any drinking water supply receiving that runoff. Wetlands are an essential part of the Cape's ecosystem with a wide reach. As both breeding grounds and as part of migratory flyways,  these areas are critical for survival of many avian species. Wetlands provide areas for fish breeding, and cover for young ocean dwelling fish that is critical for their survival. Physical and biological protection of these areas is needed.

Try drought tolerant plants and xeriscaping (landscaping with plants that need little water) and natives. Use mulch to hold in moisture to reduce the need for watering. Although many perennials only bloom a short time, the overall garden landscape can be designed so that there is always something in bloom and that the plants that aren't flowering have interesting leaves. Match the plant to the setting (soil, water and light) and it will not need "help" so much.

C\nNot much fertilizer - at max, a bit under the 3 blueberry bushes in March and when they are blooming and when they set berries, maybe one pitcher at most of miracle grow water in the spring on the leaves of the flower plants if they aren't established (for the whole garden, not per plant).

Fertilizer Application\nFertilizer would be the most easily controlled. One can simply not use it, or adjust the type or amounts and timing most appropriate for the plant to maximize uptake and minimize runoff. One cannot stop using the bathroom and it would be unhealthy and impractical to stop washing ourselves, our dishes and our clothes! Stormwater runoff from impervious surfaces can be controlled by holding systems and treatment systems, but it will still run over land.

Water for household pets, Drinking non-bottled water, Other household cleaning (such as mopping and scrubbing), Doing the laundry, Cleaning the dishes, Food Prep (boiling water, washing fruits and vegetables, etc.), Flushing the toilet, Showering\nUnless they are newly planted specimens or fruit-bearing berry bushes, I rarely water in-ground plants (maybe if there has been no rain for a week and a half and it's been broiling sun that whole time and they are in flower and truly wilting and at risk of death).  I choose natives perennials that can tolerate dry conditions. If a grass can't survive without fertilizer, it doesn't belong in my yard. If I do water plants, they get a solid drenching and then nothing for a long time again.  Frequent watering makes the plant get lazy and keep shallow roots -which need more watering in dry weather.
replies: Choosing native plantings is a great solution as they are used to the environment and won't be as stressed as something that needs to struggle to adjust.\\ Great points!

response: The big issue is carrying capacity and the issue of the tipping point.  These polishing ideas work but only as long as we are in a sustainable condition.  If we exceed the tipping point then all bets are off an we are in free fall.  We cannot expect that the environment can assimilate an unlimited amount of our pollution and survive.
Would not install one, no matter what\nBetter ways of dealing with the issue than re-inventing the wheel and going back a layer in technology.

I prefer to pay for sewers; the natural environment as a method of controlling nitrogen is messy and untested.\nWe have eclipsed the natural systems carrying capacity.  That means we are putting in more than the system can handle.  Therefore we need to do more to help the natural systems overcome the pollution load ie: sewers.  If we do not act we could in fact exceed the tipping point where no matter what we do we cannot overcome the decline.  This is real and a serious potential threat.

The county government is the only rational entity that has the power, capacity and authority to provide a comprehensive plan to dealing with the crisis.  Trying to deal with the issue locally is like trying to heard cats.

Be proactive rather than reactive.  Take control of development and mandate smart growth initiatives through smart zoning and good planning.  And provide appropriate infrastructure to encourage growth where you want it to occur.

Magically give septic tanks the power to remove all nutrients from the discharge. Then eliminate the accumulated nutrients already part of the sink in our bay, harbors, lakes and ponds.  Scrub the nutrient pollution from the air and groundwater.    That would do it!

By choosing the right path and the right technology and creative financing options.  It will not work if it is following the same old technologies and the same old financing options.  I was active in the Town of Yarmouth efforts and watched the debacle as the proposal crashed and burned at town meeting.  We need to get creative to solve the problem and we need to get creative to pay for it.  We also need to find funding from outside the community ie; the federal government and state government to lessen the burden or the Yarmouth scenario will just repeat itself across the cape and we will continue to see a decline of our oceans.  Education alone is not going to do it.  People need to see that the best approach has been selected at the least cost.  Watch the video trailer I posted in the soapbox

Share the cost regardless of age or income\nWe cannot avoid the issue of over burden any sector for the solution, by decreasing the cost for one segment we will have to increase the cost on another.  There is no silver bullet, we all have to pay to restore and protect our environment.  It's just a fact of life.  The only answer would be to provide state and federal tax deductions to those of marginal income to lessen the pain.  Creating tax credits for investing in sewer technology like renewable energy is another possibility.

The motels and other facilities providing these accommodation will be tying into the sewers, their sewer fees will pay for these added costs.  It is already being paid for by the fact that these facilities will need to connect to sewers, they already are paying for the water they use.

State or Federal Grants, Other (tell us)\nWe need to change the formula, instead of just sewering and paying to get rid of the pollution lets create valuable alternative resources from our waste stream.  By doing this and using the raw materials cost of the alternative resources to help subsidize the wastewater treatment we will be reducing cost, enhancing our sustainability and creating good paying jobs and a new industry to employ our local workers.  This is not just an idea it is a reality with algae based wastewater treatment having been developed by a local company.  This will not just create a local solution from a local company it will create a windfall through the export of this concept across the planet.
replies: I think you are on the right track Brian and I applaud you for your creative solutions. I'd really like to see the work that you are doing at the Zoo Aquarium. Would you be willing to give me a tour sometime?\\ Sure, any time.  I'm there quite a bit.

response: I can help contribute to our economic health and our future by creating vibrant sustainable village centers and bringing about technology solutions to solve our environmental crisis.  By doing this we will be re-vitalizing our local economy, and creating a vital shift in enhancing our competitive advantage while also restoring the natural environment which is what most people come here for in the first place.  Right now we have a crisis in aging building stock causing us to fall behind in competitive advantage and our pollution is impacting the quality of the experience visitors are having.  As this gets worse things will get worse and we will continue our long slide into local decline.  We need to create opportunities for our your folks or we are going to be in really big trouble.  We need to source talent locally in solving our problems, because in solving our problems we will be creating a valuable resource for export to help other communities solve their problems.  By utilizing algae as a wastewater treatment methodology we can have an impact on the nutrient pollution, global warming and create a new biotechnology sector with good paying jobs for our young folks keeping them here.  By building sustainable village centers we will be able to increase housing density and affordability which will allow us to bring down the cost of housing, which is critical to the future of cape Cod as well.

Retail trade, healthcare and accommodations and food service are the three most significant areas of economic activity in our pizza.  All of these are also related to the quality of our environment, all of these are also related to our tourism industry and our aging population which is growing at the expense of our younger population which is decreasing because of high cost of living and a lack of good paying jobs.  This is another crisis which could be impacted by what we do about saving our environment but only if we think local in our choice of solutions and those carrying out those solutions.

There are a number of sources for the pollution causing the eutrophication, some that we can do something about some that are beyond our control.  Nutrients come from the atmosphere from burning fossil fuels, which is beyond our ability to control because it is carried by the atmosphere from far away, Nutrients come from natural decomposition of detritus from plant and animal life which again we can do little about as it is part of the cycle of life, Nutrients come from road runnoff which is a problem we can and must do something about, and from chemical lawn fertilizer which we can do something about, and a major part of it comes from our septic systems which we can clearly do something about.  Another major source of nitrogen is nitrogen already in the benthic environment in the form of dead algae resulting from past algae blooms due to the amount of time that this problem has been going on.  In many cases this represents a significant percentage of the total nitrogen in the environment.  Perhaps we should also look at removing this sink/source from our bays and ponds as well.  Phosphorus is another key nutrient, this again comes from our septic systems, from soaps detergents and also from fertilizer use.  Both of these need pollutants to be dealt with now.

Eel Grass\nIt isn't a "if it went away" it's pretty well gone from my bay.  I miss the scallops, northern puffer and pipe fish the most.  They all had depended upon a healthy ecosystem and the eel grass to survive.  I've been a scuba diver since the early 60s and I watched the horrible decline year by year.  I tried to tell others but no one wanted to listen, or said that they didn't believe it.  That was what prompted me to form The Lewis Bay Research Center, to track the decline and document what we had lost and are still losing.  Desperation is a great motivator.

Once upon a time on cape Cod our bays were pristine and our community was rural.  I have worked in oyster aquaculture and I've had done scalloping on Lewis Bay in the late 1960s with my dad.  Back then eelgrass was plentiful and scallop harvests amounted to 1500 bushels for the season.  Fish were different as well, northern puffers and pipe fish were somewhat common, now they are gone as well as the eelgrass.  The environment has now deteriorated to the point where they are no longer there. Instead algae blooms have taken over, so much algae washes up along the shore that it takes a backhoe to haul it away in many cases.  The algae is natures response to the pollution in an attempt to re-balance the system now out of whack by pollution from our septic tanks, road runoff and lawn fertilizer .  There is plenty of fertilizer just flowing from our septic systems and lawns to make this happen, you should consider this fact before you apply your next bag of fertilizer or you are asked to vote to approve sewers for your area.  We have to make serious changes to save our oceans.

As a waterfront property owner i would expect to see the impacts of reducing my nitrogen footprint relatively quickly if I were the only problem, unfortunately there are many properties far from the water which will take years to mitigate.  We have no time to wait to bring about solutions we could be looking at the tipping point ecologically.
I will sewer my property, I will buy local farm products and I will reduce my use of fossil fuel based energy, I will walk and bicycle more and try to use public transportation.
We wish we could flush and forget, but that is a very bad bet, which has lead to a sea of regret as we now know the results that we get.

Sandy Pond in Yarmouth is showing signs of eutrophic conditions with algae blooms now shifting the ecosystems from the pristine waters that I remember swimming and scuba diving in the pond during the 19760s and 70s.  This is a serious threat to the health of the pond and along with the accumulation of detritus from years of vegetative deposition the pond is showing declining water quality conditions.  Though our primary focus has been on nitrogen and the coastal waters we should be working to control phosphorous at the same time.  Otherwise we will be solving a problem, being left to then come back again and solve another problem.  I have witnessed the shift in ecosystems balance first hand and having lived here for 60 years I have the anecdotal knowledge to know what the conditions were like before the great development boom.

[[[41.6572622681607, -70.24985986328124]]]\nMy family had assembled over 80 acres of land around Sandy Pond in West Yarmouth.  In the early 1980s the Town of Yarmouth took this land by eminent domain in a process far less than equitable.  This was a double edged sword, on the one side my family was deprived of a significant asset for far less than it's real market value causing economic hardships for all of my family members still being felt today.  However it did preserve the land permanently as a public park for all to enjoy Including myself and my children which is a clear value for future generations of Cape Codders.  It is part of the Cape Cod Pathways network and is one of the most beautiful places in the central Cape with easy access and a public swimming beach.  Though no development exists anywhere on the property there are significant signs of eutrophic influences indicating that the groundwater background levels are a problem.

Wetlands Protection, Drinking Water Standards, Stormwater Runoff\nDue to the nature of our region we have a sole source aquifer which supplies all of our drinking water.  The quality of our drinking water is an indicator of the pollution in our groundwater which is ultimately the vehicle that carries the excess nutrients to the coastal waters.  In many area wetlands create a natural buffer by up-taking some of these nutrients as they flow toward the seas.  Natural attenuation is the least costly and most natural process for treating nutrients entering our coastal waters.  Another significant source or nutrient pollution is runoff from impervious surfaces, by channeling runoff through vegetative buffers such as wetlands much of the pollution carried in the flow can be eliminated.

Utilizing natural vegetative cover rather than a carpet of grass is a great way to go.  He can also look into the use of algae as an organic alternative to his chemical fertilizer application.  Doing these things can have a huge impact on his net nitrogen footprint.
replies: Exactly. Native vegetation!

response: B\nI use algae from my photobioreactor to feed my lawn.  Several hundred gallons of liquid algae have been applied to my lawn this year without a single drop of chemical fertilizer use.  My lawn is healthy green and sustainable.  My garden is the same, flowers, vegetables and sunflowers have all done very well fed purely by algae.  The algae breaks down organically rather than being "released" by water which creates a gradual decomposition and prevents the nutrient compounds from leaching into the soil.

Wastewater\nWith innovative wastewater treatment technology we have the ability to remove nearly all of the nitrogen pollution from the wastewater.  Most technologies utilize complex processes to change the nitrogen to a it's state as a gas.  Newer technologies are utilizing the process exemplified in our ecosystems, algae.  This method reduces costs and operating complexity while also removing the nutrients to levels far lower than mechanical systems Nitrogen discharge levels of .3 PPM anb Phosphorous levels as low as .01 PPM.  The process utilizes the natural photosynthesis which also consumes carbon dioxide and releases pure oxygen in the process.  Photosynthesis is a natural process used by plants to create food for growth of the organisms.  The nutrients are therefore re-claimed in the algae which is then harvested to create a valuable biotech resource.  The algae is also an ideal organic fertilizer which will not contribute to the nutrient pollution issue like chemical fertilizers.
replies: I'd like to know more about this.

response: [[[41.651105778001586, -70.24985986328124]]]\nI am a native Cape Codder who grew up on Lewis Bay in West Yarmouth who witnessed the ecological crisis first hand.  This prompted me to form the Lewis Bay Research Center which has been engaged in water quality monitoring and coastal ecosystems research for over 2 decades.  We have real time web based monitoring technology in Lewis Bay and we have established a Research Lab on Parker's River to study the problems and bring forth innovative solutions.  I am also engaged in the development of sustainable village center infrastructure technology utilizing algae which represents an exciting and sustainable solution to our wastewater crisis by creating valuable resources from the waste water including an alternative water supply for re-use water and a valuable algae based biotech product from the waste stream.  We installed the first membrane bioreactor technology in New England at a 0 discharge laundromat in West Yarmouth in 1992 which is still operating today.

This is copied from the Resource page:SEPTIC SYSTEM FACTS85%of the development on Cape Cod uses asepticsystem for wastewater treatmentSeptic systemsremovedisease causingbacteria (pathogens), but not all the nitrogenBased on 2012 figures, the averagehousehold contributes10 poundsofnitrogenevery yearAveragecostfor the construction andmaintainance of a septic system is around$1,150every yearTo keep the system working, the septic tankshould be pumped every3-5 years1A septic system for collecting wastetypically consists of a septic tank, and aleaching field, connected by pipes. Solidwaste is collected in a buried tank andpumped out, and disposed of, at regularintervals. The remaining liquidpercolates into the ground through theleaching trench or field.Bacteria in the septic system changesthe composition of the waste as it travelsthrough the system.

He spent hours changing the angle of his land, even commenting to his partner that the predicted rainstorm might wash the fertilizer, grass seed & soil off the lawn and into the eel grass bed they enjoy observing so much. Months later a portion of the eel grass bed had died, very few fish seemed to be visiting and a concerned friend commented, "The only way to save your oxygen depleted eel grass now is to put some living oysters out there and see if they can help your eel grass breathe again."

response: According to the charts, the upper level samples show that the phosphorus concentration stays consistent at about 25 from 2005 to 2008. The lower level samples show that the phosphorus concentration increases from 15 to 115 from 2005 to 2008. This means the lower level samples went from Oligotrophic to HyperEutrophic over 3 years. This indicates the ponds are very nutrient rich but have very low oxygen levels preventing life from functioning at lower depths which will have a drastic impact on marine life.

Wastewater treatment plants remove nitrogen in two ways:1. Somewhere on the order of 10 mg/L of influent nitrogen is converted to the bacteria that end up as waste activated sludge. Because nitrogen makes up about twelve percent of the dry weight of secondary sludge, and a slightly smaller percentage of primary sludge_ Every 8-10 mg/L of effluent TSS contains one mg/L of _suspended_ nitrogen.2. Treatment plants convert the majority of the incoming nitrogen from one form to another in a three step biological process, ammonification, nitrification, and dentrification.Don't try this at home.

Eel Grass\nWith 30 of the 32 bays studied on Cape Cod suffering from elevated nitrogen it's no wonder we have seen a steady decrease in eel grass populations. Habitat is the key to healthy wildlife populations and eel grass was our key habitat matrix for all of the organisms you have listed with the exception of the more offshore species: codfish. Hence, when we lose the grass many of our other animals are suffering.

A small backhoe was being used to move a bag of fertilizer from a barge near the shore. The bag broke open and spilled into the bay initiating an algae bloom which lasted for the next 5 days. The algae blocked light from reaching the eelgrass which died back thus causing fish to migrate from the area and sedentary oysters to suffer from the lack of oxygen.

Our wastewater treatment systems do little to reduce nitrogen levels in our effluent. As of 2005, this pond was floating dangerously on the border between mesotrophic and eutrophic. Then, over the course of slightly over three years, the lower levels of the water column (deeper sections of the pond) quickly became hypereutrophic while the upper levels maintained. This seems to indicate two things. First, eutrophications begins at lower levels of the water column where nutrients pool and progresses upward. Second, the rate at which eutrophication progresses increases exponentially the further along it gets. This can be inferred from it having taken until 2005 to reach the threshhold of beging labeled eutrophic and then crusing through eutrophia right to hypereutrophia in just over three years.

If everyone contributed equally, If the state and federal government helped\nEveryone in a watershed contributes to the pollution of that watershed. Since the total nitrogen contributed to a watershead must be reduced everyone must contribute to the infrastructure to solve the problem. Dense housing areas, business concentrations, and large private devolepments will need to be sewered due to their concentrated contributions to nitrogen pollution. Many lower density,  remote, or special areas will not need sewering as the impact of their nitrogen pollution is reduced by natural processes within the watershed.

Those households or businesses in an adjoining town, but in the watershed, should be treated finnancialy as if they reside in the managed watershed. Their community would collect and reimburse appropriate revenues.

Communities must not make decisions baised on bad or unproven science. Many of our well intended enviormental laws now have negative impact. The simple disposal of clean, steralized, low nitrogen waste water should be disposed of on the surface in natural woodlands like conservation areas. This water would become polished and find its way into our aquifiers and watersheds for reuse.

We live surrounded by ocean water and pull our drinking water from an aquifer below where we live. In some places like Provincetown the salt water is mixing with our fresh water, but the main issue is pollution of the aquifer. Measured substances like nutrient levels and fecal matter and unmeasured substances like caffeine and medicines are going into the aquifer much faster than they are being naturally filtered out. Nature cannot keep up with the negative inputs from human activities.

Jason could implement a series of practices, such as: 1) replacing lawn with native ground cover, 2) using indigenous plants, 3) getting a soil test before adding minerals, 4) planting a mix of grasses 5) leaving grass clippings in the lawn and not mowing below 3" high, 6) eliminate the use of chemical pesticides and fertilizers by favoring organic soil amendments and natural week and pest supression agents such as corn gluten to cultivate a health microbe environment. In the area I am most familiar with, the heaviest population density is in areas with less, often much less, than 10 years travel time of Nitrogen through groundwater to the water.  I personally live directly on Waquoit Bay, so the nitrogen in my septic system reaches the bay within less than a year.  If we could magically manage to reduce by 80 percent the nitrogen from all of the 8000 or so homes and businesses with septic system in the watersheds of Little Pond, Great Pond, Green Pond, Bournes Pond and Waquoit Bay south of Route 28 it would have a substantial impact on nitrogen entering these estuaries in less than 5 years.  Our current CWMP calls for taking such action within the next 20 years or so.  That is too long to wait and I hope we can find ways of taking meaningful action sooner.

I could probably do most to lower my footprint by purchasing more local food and driving a more energy-efficient car.  My diet is in general fairly nitrogen efficient.  But that is on the side of how much nitrogen I am producing that can go into the environment.  This question does not seem to be about what I could do to reduce the nitrogen entering the environment, or how I could recycle nitrogen and other nutrients.

Looks like samples were taken each year for four years during the summer months.  The upper levels showed no increase in concentrations of phosphorous over the period.  The lower levels showed variable but increasing average levels of phosphorous over the period.  Though a 4 year period is too short to eliminate yearly fluctuations and transient factors, taken at face value the fact that surface samples show no increase while deeper samples do show an increase might be interpreted to mean that there was more phosphorous in the ponds in years 3 and 4 but that increasing biological activity in the upper levels kept measured phosphorous constant there, but a lack of mixing of the pond and perhaps increasing shading of the lower levels led to a rise of phosphorous levels there to match the rise in inflow of phosphorous.  But I don't have any specialized knowledge, and the period of time is too short to infer increasing phosphorous loading from development.

He can follow the organic lawn care guidelines developed by FACES for the Falmouth Friendly Lawn Program in 2005.  The Falmouth WQMC is preparing an updated information sheet based on these guidelines and other information to go with the new Nutrient Management by-law.  He might attend an informational seminar given by an organic lawn-care professional such as Chip Osborne.  Basically, fertilize only in spring and fall, using organic and slow release products, no more than 1 pound per 1000 sq ft, overseed with Cape seed mixtures [no bluegrass], in the summer cut high (3"), water only when needed and then in early morning and no more than once a week an inch at a time.  You can have a good, well-cared-for lawn if you follow organic principles, and will have fewer pest problems as well.  If everyone were to follow these guidelines it would make a significant difference to the nitrogen load to our estuaries - up to 5 - 10 percent.

Cape Cod is nothing without its beautiful beaches, marshes, woods - its natural beauty is what draws visitors here, time and time again (and what keeps those of us who live here year-round here). Supporting local businesses whenever possible is key - making sure we are helping those who are contributing to our economy. Think about choices - do you want to buy fruits or vegetables from a large chain, or at the farmer's market down the street? Can you purchase affordable clothing locally? Making the local choice will help the Cape's economy.

Because our economy is largely tourism based, the accomodation/food service "slice" is obviously incredibly large - but is it the most important?. Much income is generated from hotel stays and meals at restaurants, and that helps support the local economy. Yet often the service industries employ foreign or seasonal workers, and while those businesses are doing well, we have to wonder what impact they are having on our year-rounders. The large Healthcare "slice" is also important - even moreso because it provides JOBS - good paying, year round jobs for Cape Codders. When looking at the economy, a balance between the industries we have, services we provide, and good jobs we can offer are key.  We need to look at the financial sector, and professional/technical services - while they appear to be a small piece of the pie, if they were to grow, so would the year round jobs and overall year round economy for Cape Cod.

The sources that affect the Cape's nitrogen levels are largely human. Human waste contains nitrogen, and when sent into septic systems, nitrogen finds its way back into the environment, groundwater, and eventually to our ponds, bays, estuaries, and marshes. Nitrogen is also found in fertilizers, again, when applied to lawns and gardens, it finds its way back into the water system.
Sea Birds\nThe birds are such a part of the landscape of the Cape, from watching them in flight, while they hunt, and hearing their cries and calls throughout the day.

At one time, we didn't think twice about taking a bag of fertilizer and dumping it in our yard with a backhoe. . Over time, though, excess nutrients have built up in our waterways, destroying the habitat for our fish, and killing off the eelgrass. Oysters can actually be effective in helping to clean the water, as their filter-feeder nature can help reduce the excess nutrients.

We should be working on solutions NOW. A solution should be determined as quickly as possible to stop any further damage and begin the healing. It will take a significant amount of time to see results, so the sooner we begin, the better.

To reduce the level of nitrogen pollution, we can try to decrease the use of fertilizers, fossil fuels, and the amount of waste discarded into major bodies of water.

Septic systems are similar to the "polishing process". Septic systems are used to treat and dispose of waste water. A septic tank's purpose is to separate solids from waste water and to collect and break apart as much solid material as possible, while allowing the liquid waste water to enter the drain field. After solids settle in the septic tank, the liquid waste water is released into the drain field. The soil below the drain field provides the final treatment and disposal of the septic tank waste water. After the waste water has passed into the soil, organisms in the soil treat it before it filters downward and outward, eventually entering ground or surface water. This system purifies our waste water so that it is safe for us to drink and clean with. The "polishing process" is similar because it removes the impurities from water as well, just in a more natural, environment-friendly way.

response: If I were in charge, I would begin by solving some environmental problems, such as waste water, which would hopefully make Cape Cod an even more desirable place to live.  That would increase the young population, who could create more jobs and boost the overall economy.  As long as the environment is healthy and well maintained, the rest of our problems are easily solved.
replies: I agree. If the young population saw how beautiful the Cape is, they would most likely want to stay.\\ It IS really beautiful, but beauty only goes so far. We need jobs that pay decently and stuff to do after work!

response: I think an interesting graph to include in her project would show past nitrogen levels in the bay she visits, and what the future levels are on pace to be if we don't act now.  The graph could be accompanied by an analysis of how much algae is produced by a certain amount of nitrogen, and how long it will take for all plant life in the bay to completely decompose.

If I paid based on how much wastewater I generate\nThis would promote conservation as far as the production of wastewater, which would help to solve our problem in a completely different way.  Also, this would seem to be the most fair solution, because those who produce more wastewater are more a part of the problem, and should therefore contribute to the solution more than those who conserve water.  However, there should be an option to donate extra as a voluntary contribution, because many people may be willing to pay more just to get rid of the problem.

15 town groups\nDividing the groups by town is a good way to ensure that the number of different members is enough to make a fair decision, and it would be the most simple solution, because each town already meets at a separate form of town meeting, where the discussion could be held.  Also, the boundaries for each town are set, so there would be less confusion as far as that aspect goes.

I live in the Megansett Harbor watershed.  I swim there often, which means that I must be cautious about what I put into the groundwater, because it will eventually end up polluting the harbor.  I also enjoy watching the marine life there, which could be harmed by any sort of pollution, and the entire ecosystem could be thrown off balance.

Allow development rights in remote areas to be transferred to areas where wastewater infrastructure is present, Allow more development, but only where it currently exists\nI believe that allowing growth only where we already have development will significantly reduce the cost of eliminating nitrogen pollution from future residences, because they will already have a wastewater infrastructure, and we will not have to install another one.  Also, this will ensure that much of our natural environment remains untouched by future construction, which could lead to even more environmental problems.

No\nIf nitrogen is not removed before it reaches the groundwater, it pollutes the marine environment and causes eutrophication.  Due to the high percentage of older homes on Cape Cod, there are many septic systems that are old as well, and aren't fitted to remove nitrogen.  If we are to solve our waste water problem once and for all, we need to install modern septic systems in a lot more residences.

I think the top three reasons people come to live on the Cape are its beaches, its natural beauty, and its relatively clean environment.  Surrounded by water, it is a perfect place to swim and boat in the ocean.  Also, Cape Cod is home to many plant and animal species that once thrived in the abundance of natural areas.  Due to the lack of industrial factories, our air is also cleaner than the air of some other regions of Massachusetts.  All these and more are reasons that we should work hard to protect our marine ecosystem from pollution.
replies: I agree with most of your reasons. However, I have seen data that suggests air quality on the Cape is often much worse than Boston. The Cape receives emissions from coal burning plants and trash burning facilities in Eastern Mass. Although it may seem that the air should be cleaner because of the minimal number of significant sources on the Cape, it is not at all immune to the pollutants coming from the westerly direction.  The Cape often doesn't attain air quality standards for ozone.  I think people get the impression that the air is cleaner than it really is because of the breeze and the stunning colors of the sky that draw in so many artists.\\ That's interesting.  I never knew that.  Thanks!

response: Some objects in my home that illustrate a similar process to the "polishing" of water include door mats, lint collectors in driers, and paper towels.  We use all of these things to remove unwanted materials and dirt from objects, just like natural systems clean the water of pollutants.

Other (tell us)\nAs long as the cost was reasonable, I would certainly be willing to have an "eco-toilet" installed.  They sound like a great way to reduce nitrogen pollution in our groundwater, and I would be willing to pay for that.  If everyone installed one of these, Cape Cod would have a much more healthy environment, and we wouldn't have to worry about excess algae growth in our ponds and other marine areas.

We should rely on natural systems to remove as much nitrogen as possible in as many locations as possible, regardless of cost.\nIf there is any way to remove nitrogen naturally, we should jump at that opportunity.  Sewer systems must be maintained, and will most likely cause more trouble than they prevent.  On the other hand, natural solutions are long-lasting and will benefit the environment in other ways as well.

I think the Barnstable County government should be responsible for dealing with our waste water problem, because they are able to coordinate a solution with all of the towns on Cape Cod.  They may not be able to do the job alone, seeings as how large it has become, but they should definitely play a major role in finding a solution.

If I could travel back in time, I would advise policy makers in the past to take immediate action to prevent the pollution of groundwater.  One of the major problems now is that the pollution has become so out of control, that we can't think of a logical way to stop it.  Had the problem been stopped at its source many years ago, we would have a much easier time dealing with it today.

I believe the ideal super hero would be able to convert waste water into pure drinking water.  This would require an advanced filtration system that was able to remove all harmful chemicals from the water.  This would be great, because the main inconvenience that comes with waste water is that we can't just store it somewhere, or easily clean it, so it ends up polluting our marine environments.  Not only would this hero protect the environment; they would provide us with an essential part of life - water.

Jim can do this by simply explaining each scenario.  For instance, how would funding the waste water plan affect the near future?  What would happen if we didn't fund it?  Most likely, he will be able to convince the voters that if the problem is not dealt with now, it will only become worse.

Share the costs, but discount based on income\nDiscounting based on income would seem to make the most sense, because someone's income is directly related to how much they can reasonably pay in taxes.  On the other hand, discounting based on age is not necessarily fair, as age is not directly related to one's wealth.

I do think it would be fair to charge summer visitors, because they have plenty of reason to want to help improve the Cape's water infrastructure, as they will probably be visiting again in the future.  If they don't contribute, there is no guarantee their next visit will be as comfortable.  We wouldn't have to charge much, anyways, because there would be two or three times the population to distribute the cost between.

Expansion of Bottle Bill, Rooms/Meals Tax Increases, A "Flush" Tax\nI think both the expansion of bottle bill and a "flush" tax would promote conservation in areas that tend to be extremely wasteful.  Less plastic water bottles would end up in landfills, and people would soon learn to conserve water, not taking it for granted.  Also increasing rooms/meals tax is a good way to take advantage of our large tourism industry here on Cape Cod.

I think we all can help Cape Cod's economic health by buying local produce.  Not only does this reduce transportation costs and therefore pollution; it supports our local agriculture industry in a way that nothing else can.  This allows both our environment and our economy to thrive, and everyone can be a part of it.

On Cape Cod, three very important parts of our economy are tourism, agriculture (cranberries), and marine research.  Many people come to Cape Cod during the summer to experience its beautiful beaches.  Also, we have a very large cranberry industry, and are home to some of the most acclaimed marine research facilities, attracting many scientists from around the world.

On Cape Cod, our "sources" of nitrogen all revolve around our waste products, as our groundwater is connected to many bodies of water that support aquatic life.  For example, our sewage systems, storm drains, and garbage disposal all produce dangerous amounts of nitrogen that ultimately ends up polluting ponds, bays, estuaries, and marshes around Cape Cod.

Eel Grass\nWithout eel grass, the whole ecosystem would be thrown off balance.  Fish, such as the ones listed as possible answers to this question, rely on eel grass for food.  A large and widespread death of eel grass would therefore kill off equally as many fish, which are a staple part of our diets as residents of Cape Cod.

As the man spread a bag of fertilizer, one of many, on his lawn using a backhoe, he thought he was helping the grass grow, and helping the environment in turn.  What he did not realize, was that the chemicals in the fertilizer mixed with his sewage in the ground water, and caused a large growth of algae in a nearby pond.   The algae blocked the sunlight from reaching the eelgrass, whose imminent death led to the deaths of hundreds of fish, leaving an enormous oyster population to take over the pond.

Well, we are doing a pretty good job already it seems to me.  Cape Cod folks are pretty engaged in these issues, and solutions to these environmental problems are in the works.  Falmouth, for instance, has come up with a pretty good plan to reduce wastewater nitrogen inputs into our harbors that uses a balanced approach, including measures to reduce nitrogen at its sources, barriers to trap nitrogen already in the groundwater, and targeted sewering.  So, I guess I would suggest we keep doing more of the same!

Lawns and gardens can be a "polisher" as well as a source of pollution. It depends on whether you apply fertilizer, or let natural decomposition take it's course. Most superheroes are smart, and they'll go for the easiest way to weaken their opponent first. That's why my superhero would tackle chemical fertilizers first with her superhuman convincing powers-- they are simply unnecessary and contribute more than we think to the nutrient loading problem. Second, with her almighty strength and ingenuity, she would build advanced stormwater catchment systems with constructed wetlands in areas that don't have them-- and bolster those that already exist.

response: Oysters\nI'd miss oysters the most (although scallops and striped bass are a close second and third) not only because they're delicious, I enjoy harvesting them using our family shellfishing permit, but also because of the value of oyster shells. I learned in a New York Times article following Hurricane Sandy that much of the damage sustained in the NY metro area's bays and estuaries could have been prevented had the reefs of oyster shells accumulated for eons had been left in place instead of being gathered and used for road beds and dozens of other purposes aimed at advancing civilization. How ironic that this humble shellfish could play such an important role if left in its original location, sparing from devastation the very civilization that it was instead used to build up. And that's why I like oysters.

Free removal of collected urine\nSince the urine diverting system means that once it is collected it is turned into fertilizer, which can be sold, it seems to me that it should be collected for free.  This would be very similar to the way that recyclables are collected in our town dumps and then sold on the market for reuse. Nitrogen fertilizer is a valuable commodity.

We should rely on natural systems to remove as much nitrogen as possible in as many locations as possible, regardless of cost.\nThe article recently in the Cape Cod Times regarding the federal funds that have been received to restore the Herring River in Wellfleet and South Truro is the latest example of the need to make the use of the natural systems in the Cape's ecosystem the first solution to our pollution problems.  Over the past several years quite a few bridges with culverts that restricted water flow have been upgraded so as to restore the cleansing actions of the tidal flows.  We need to identify all of the flow constrictors that have been created of the past one hundred years and then use local, county, state and federal funds to pay for the correction of these problems which we created for ourselves.This will permit marshes to be restored thus using the nitrogen and also the granting of more shellfish grants that will then use oysters and clams to help clean up the pollution  Technology is not the first solution of our problems when our natural systems can be used to solve many of our problems.

As an elected official representing the residents of your town, you need to educate yourself so you can better persuade your town's residents about the problems and the solutions to our Wastewater Crisis.  If you and the people you represent don't do it, who will?

In the seventies when it became obvious that the Mid-Cape Highway was going to cause development to explode on the Cape, the towns and the county should have thought about what impact this development would have on the Cape and its natural systems in the same way that in the sixties local residents understood what unfettered development would have meant for the Outer Cape and thus the Cape Cod National Seashore was established. This type of development planning would have resulted in the requirement that developers include not just water distribution infrastructure but also sewerage infrastructure in their developments along with other essential utilities.  If these infrastructure had been installed then would have resulted in significatnt cost savings compared to what its going to cost now and in the future.We have know for way too many years that fertilizers result in too many nutrients becoming part of the runoff of both homes and golf courses.  Limits on the use could have been implemented years ago.  Another issue that is finally being dealt with in the past few years that has been obvious for years is the need of increasing of the size of the culverts under bridges over various waterways that have restricted tidal flows that flush the marshlands and allow for the runoff coming from surrounding development to move out of the embayments and to the ocean quicker.  Having come to the Cape nearly twenty-four years ago with a regional planning background of some forty years, I can insure all that nearly all parts of the United States have lacked an understanding of the importance of making the environment part of the planning process in the same way that today's planning has finally gotten it but in many cases way too late.  The Next Big Fontier for town and regional planning is to understand that telecommunication infrastructure is just an essential to the planning and development process as transportation, water, electric and gas utilities.

The Cape's Super Hero would have the power to Educate and Persuade all of the residents and businesses that we have a Major Problem and that there are solutions to fix them.  The best way to communicate and persuade is by the Commission and our Cape Cod leadership to use the Community Access channels and resources available in each town to educate and persuade that what these community communications resources were created for and folks are not recognizing their value in this effort. Playing online games doesn't reach a wide enough audience but the Cable Access Channels do.

First, Jim needs to become totally familiar with the problems and the solutions so that he can better educate and persuade the participants at his Town Meeting.  If he is not educated and prepared, he is wasting everyone time.Second, he should also go to his local community access center and produce an informational television program that can be cablecast on the local access channel on the cable system so that he can begin this important education process before he walks into a Selectman's meeting or Town Meeting.  These community communications resources are available in every town of the Cape.  It is extremely important for all elected local, county and state official to use them since this will make their job easier and will bring the community support necessary to solve these problems.

Share the costs, but discount based on income\nThose who can afford to pay more should pay more.  We sure don't have equitable of wealth on the Cape much less anywhere else in the state or the world.  This is yet another reason why the Cape Cod state legislative delegation need to insure that we have a more equitable return of funds from the state based on the property taxes. This would enable the Cape towns and the County to subsidize older residents who are on fixed income.

The solution to all of our water infrastructure needs for both drinking and disposal has several answers.  My need to come up with an estimated cost to the necessary replacement and improvements of this vital infrastructure and then determine if we are actually charging residents and business their fair share of these costs.  If they are not, then we need to raise rates so everyone pays for these costs whether resident or visitor.  We also need to do a much better job of managing our water infrastructure since much of it is too old and needs to be replaced thus reducing the amount of water lost through leaks in the old infrastructure and we also need to install sensors to monitor the delivery of the water supply and the disposal of waste water.  This is why we need to insure that all homes, institutions and businesses are connect in the Last Mile to the OpenCape Middle Mile telecommunications infrastructure.  In the same way that utilities are now managing their delivery of energy using Smart Electric Grids, we need to also implement Smart Water Grids throughout the Cape.  Smart Management of all of our utilities and appliances is what the Internet of Things is all about. Welcome to the 21st Century!

State or Federal Grants, Rooms/Meals Tax Increases, Sharing Existing Facilities\nLocal municipal and county governmental bodies have made zoning and development decisions in the past that have contributed to all of these problems but we as the residents have enabled these bad decisions.  We all need to insure that the town boards and committees do the right thing in the future.  So, we all need to be much more aware of what is going on during these decision making processes and speak out in in every forum and using every communications platform available.  We need to take our towns back from realtors and developers who have way too much power in the past.  By doing this we can insure that all solutions to solving these problems will be paid for using local, county, state and federal funds and everyone will pay their fair share.

As a community media and telecommunications infrastructure consultant, I can bring to every sector of the Cape population and economy an understanding of the importance of a high-speed information and communications infrastructure and all of the various applications that run on these networks so that all of the services needed by a resident or visitor population can be provided.  This is want a Global Information and Knowledge Economy requires in the 21st Century.

Rather than focus on just three. I am going to combine two so I can also have two more that I think are very important.  The two I will combine are accommodation/food services and retail trade since as we have known for quite a few years the main thing that visitors to the Cape is shop and eat.  The Cape is not just a place to go to the Beach but also a shopping place where the slogan is "Don't you just love a Bargain". But that doesn't even account for it all since there are so many specialty boutiques, book stores and art and crafts galleries here also. The Cape is also awash in wonderful restaurants, super markets and local farmers markets.The other two that are so important to the Cape are educational services and healthcare and social assistance.  Both of these important sectors of the economy provide Cape Codders of all  ages with the education they need to be actively involved and working in out 21st Century. Knowledge and Information Economy and to become and remain Healthy and Happy so they can contribute in every way they can to the Cape, our region and the nation. A very important new information and communications infrastructure the Cape now has is the OpenCape Middle Mile Network, which is connecting all of our Community Anchor Institutions including our schools and healthcare facilities to world class, high speed global networks so the Cape can be both Local and Global simunlaneourly.

There are many sources we can deal with since they are local and then there are sources we cannot prevent locally.  The local sources are our methods of treating and not treating human waste since most Cape towns have not installed sewerage systems and waste treatment plants. In our homes we must stop using cleaning products, which contain phosphorus. Another major source is all the fertilizers that we use to make our gardens and golf courses so beautiful and green.  These can be dealt with locally if we act decisively and soon.  One of the other sources that we cannot deal with locally but rather must be solved nationally and internationally are the nutrients, sulfuric acid and other toxins in our atmosphere and thus our rain water.  Global pollution and climate change cannot be dealt with locally but we must be part of the Global Solution.

Striped Bass\nThe fresh caught local seafood of the Cape along with its environment has been the reason people have lived here and traveled from around the world to visit here from the Native Americans, to the Vikings, Basque and many other Europeans for centuries and more recently during the European Age of Global Exploration and Settlement. If we current residents and visitors to the Cape don't control nutrient runoff into our surrounding waters, we will eliminate one of the main reason to live or visit the Cape.  If we don't deal with it now, who will?

The Cape Cod ecosystem is made up of the water moving from the land, through the rivers, creeks and streams to the bays and then into to the surrounding ocean waters.  If there is too much nutrient in this system then algae, which thrives on these nutrients, will bloom and thus deprive the water and everything that lives in it, whether plants or marine life, of oxygen and they cannot survive and grow in the way they should.  These nutrients are put into the system in many ways and from many sources. For the Cape to survive and thrive we must reduce these nutrients to manageable levels.

Installation for free\nI am a huge proponent of ecotoilets. These will help solve nitrogen issues as well as reduce water use. As sea level rises and the ground water level rises, many septic systems will be flooded. Ecotoilets will provide a great option for homeowners. We need to begin now to change the public's perception of them. My suggestions include demo toilets in public areas and getting some community leaders and fearless innovators to install them in their homes and become ecotoilet ambassadors. Also, incentives should be given to developers to install them now. In the future, bylaws should be written to require them to be installed in new homes. However, I don't think it would be fair to require it yet, as public opinion first needs to be changed.

Other (Tell us)\nI am in favor of more green spaces, trees, wetlands etc. for a variety of reasons including aesthetics and quality of life. However, funding can be limited so we need to be strategic in acquiring new landholdings. Additionally, I think it is important to educate people about and demonstrate the cost savings of using green infrastructure over gray in the long run. Short term, it may seem expensive, but over many years, the green infrastructure will give you a greater return on investment.

If my contribution went to a fund dedicated to wastewater solutions only, If the state and federal government helped\nNo one wants to pay more money. A large percentage of tax revenue on Cape Cod goes out for use at the state level and never makes its way back to our towns. In most circumstances, this is appropriate as the money should go where it's needed. However, a fundamental infrastructure update is literally the reason that we pay taxes. If taxes are paid here and funds are needed here then our tax dollars should be used here.If it is necessary for us to pay additional funds, then I definitely want a guarantee that the money I'm paying is being directed appropriately into wastewater infrastructure. I have little confidence, especially as we move past the local level, that my tax dollars are being spent appropriately.

11 watershed groups\nI hesitate to suggest dividing groups along town lines. I think there's a natural inclination to focus on the well-being of your own town and to diffuse responsibility to others. I think dividing work groups along watershed lines increases the probability of having multiple towns represented in each group which, while more complicated, will likely result in a more balanced solution. I suggest 11 watershed groups because that number is far more manageable than 57.
Sandwich Harbor

Other (tell us)\nI feel like this is one of the most difficult issues on the Cape. There is always a contingent that opposes growth of any kind and another contingent that opposes any kind of restrictions to growth. As with most other things, it is a matter of balance. New development is necessary. A measured approach would allow the most critical development to proceed with caveats that require addressing wastewater issues as new spaces are built/developed. New developments should be required to include wastewater mitigation as part of their plans. Include a requirement in new developments for a specific objective (x% of nitrogen allowed or max allowances of x#) and require developers to submit their plan for compliance to the end result. People will comply with requirements to the least extent possible so I think it's important to make sure the requirements legislate the end result and not just the process.

State or Federal Grants, Sharing Existing Facilities, Other (tell us)\nEmergency & capital improvements always seem to take each town by surprise and generates a Prop 2 1/2 request. If doesn't seem as though towns are planning adequately for infrastructure needs. I think a combination of approaches is required to address this. 1) Collaborate willingly...how often do we read headlines about two towns bickering over an initiative that should be mutually beneficial? 2) Set aside a (higher?) percentage of tax revenues for infrastructure needs and do not use it for anything else. The Cape will continue to need updates, even after the wastewater problem is addressed. 3) Prioritize better. There are demands on all sides for money for projects. It seems like the least critical projects are the easiest to fund because they generate little controversy. This is understandable but not helpful in the long run.

I think it all comes down to being aware and involved in our community. This can happen in quite a few ways. Supporting local business owners and farmers contributes to our economy. Accommodation/food services - The tourist industry is the heart of our economy. Without a thriving hospitality sector, the main engine of our economy would be crippled.Arts, entertainment & recreation - I was surprised to see this was such a small slice of the pie. I think that without arts, entertainment & recreation, we lose a lot of the tourist appeal of Cape Cod. For such a small region, we have a robust artistic community.Retail trade - A lot of the jobs that are created on Cape are related to the retail trade. Without strong retail trade, a lot of the citizens on the Cape suffer.
