There and many alternative ways Jason can do to substitute the fertilizer he is using with something less harmful for the environment. Basic ingredients he uses in his cafe can help maintain an attractive property such as coffee grounds or eggshells. Coffee contains valuable nitrogen and other nutrients vital to plant growth. Since the coffee beans are broken down to a fine dust, you can apply the grounds directly to the soil without first giving it time to break down in the compost heap. Eggshells are a great source of calcium and also offer the added benefit of protecting your plants from slugs and snails.

replies: Your comment intrigued me so I went looking. I definitely found the statistics to support your statement showing 4% from septic systems. But I also found other info that suggested that it wasn't dismissed by legislators & residents just because it was a small %. It was the fastest growing source of nitrogen pollution and in the 10% of septics in  critical areas (defined as within 1000' of tidal water) 80% of that nitrogen reaches surface waters. I wonder what percentage of our septics fall within 1000' of tidal water? Made for some interesting reading and I'm going to keep looking for peer reviewed scientific studies from the region. [[[41.656588956223075, -70.25913770117187]]]\nChase Brook Park is one of Yarmouth's preservation project. Some of you may remember a night club called Rascal's located on Route 28 in West Yarmouth in the 80's and 90's. It was located by an inlet. Well it was removed and replaced by a wonderful park filled with native vegetation, a walkway to the inlet and sitting area where you can enjoy a view of the water and osprey nest. This place has special meaning as the flagpole and plaque are dedicated to my late husband, Peter Henderson.There are other similar parks in the town of Yarmouth nearby that are also preserving the land and environment, all to my knowledge are permanent. The photo shows the park when the flagpole was first added in 2002. Wetlands Protection, Hazardous Materials Impacts, Stormwater Runoff\nI selected stormwater runoff because of our low elevation because it is something that we can control. Hazardous materials because we have some control over this such as how things are disposed of and laws that can be passed regarding fertilizer and chemical use. And wetland protection as it is important for our wildlife and how they help to naturally clean our water.One thing that we need to keep in mind is that not only co other towns within our watershed impact our water, but we also need to be concerned with all of the water in the world. The oceans are connected and the atmosphere is connected. So even if we are good citizens on the Cape we can still receive negative impacts from other societies who are not.

A beautiful golf course was built overlooking the water on the Cape, using a backhoe and many a bag of fertilizer. Sadly, the wastewater problem on Cape Cod is not a laughing matter. Happily, there are far more talented comedians than I, including Seppo Leinonen, a Finnish cartoonist who created the attached cartoon. There are several other great images on his website that relate to wastewater. Check them out at www.seppo.net Environmental Cartoons. Problems of wastewater, excess nitrogen, and eutrophication are not unique to Cape Cod. Solutions exist and together we can exhibit the leadership necessary to resolve the problems and create a better Cape Cod for ourselves and for future generations. In doing so, we can serve as a positive example for other parts of the world. Let's do this!

There is opportunity here to create an knowledge economy on Cape Cod. Taking advantage of Open Cape and our rich marine science community, we could encourage growth in low impact areas such as technology and science. Additionally, the Cape is a wonderful living laboratory not only for marine science but for all the issues we've discussed in the game - wastewater, development, etc. Encouraging growth in the education sector would also bring young people, professional year round jobs, and possibly even some innovation to help solve our environmental and economic challenges.

We all depend on a clean environment! While excess nitrogen is a huge problem, there are steps we can all take to improve the situation. 1) conserve water, 2) don't use fertilizer, 3) educate others (just as Mia is doing).

If I paid based on how much wastewater I generate, If my contribution went to a fund dedicated to wastewater solutions only, If the state and federal government helped\nAny sort of wastewater cost should be directed towards wastewater solutions only. The state and federal government should help because the Cape represents a state and national resource. And then the fee should be at least in part based on what I generate.

4 sub-regional groups\nAlthough there are 57 watersheds, this many watershed groups might prove too difficult to manage. Further, 32 of those watersheds are shared among 2+ communities. Watersheds cut across town boundaries, and so should solutions. One county group might be too big and not able to address issues in adequate detail. Eleven watershed groups might still be too many groups. In my opinion, four sub-regional groups is manageable and allows for groupings of like watersheds.
Live in the Buttermilk Bay watershed. Work in the watershed that goes into the Cape Cod Canal, Buzzards Bay, and Cape Cod Bay.

Allow development rights in remote areas to be transferred to areas where wastewater infrastructure is present, Allow more development, but only where it currently exists\nStopping development is impractical, and still doesn't address the wastewater problem. Directing development to areas where it currently exists - smart growth - would help the wastewater problem because concentrated development can either take advantage of existing wastewater infrastructure or build new infrastructure that is cost effective. Smart growth also helps create walkable and bikeable communities thus reducing traffic and emissions. And smart growth leaves more open space for wildlife habitat and recreation.

Yes\nAs wastewater, particularly from septic systems, contributes the most to the Cape's nitrogen problems, replacing these systems over time with new systems that incorporate denitrification technology would help greatly. It would be good to learn more about these systems, however. How much do they cost to install? Is there added maintenance over a standard system? How effective are they at removing nitrogen? Are they as effective as standard systems at removing toxins and other nutrients?

People come to the Cape because of the beauty of our natural environment and to be near the ocean and the beach. Some people come here for a job (I did). Some people come here because it is a quiet place to retire.
The only thing I can think of is my Britta water pitcher.

Installation for free\nIt would be great to have incentives to install and maintain eco toilets. Incentives could include tax credits and/or credits to be applied towards any future sewerage connection costs. As for what it would take for me to install one, I'd need to know more about the cost of maintaining a system.

Other (Tell us)\nExpanding and enhancing the functionality of natural nitrogen processing systems should be an important part of the Cape's wastewater treatment plan. In additional to nitrogen removing benefits, natural systems have added benefits of providing wildlife habitat as well as open space and recreational space. While cost must be a consideration, I suspect natural systems may often be less costly than manufactured solutions. And they are aesthetically more pleasing! However, it is not practical everywhere.
Wastewater on Cape Cod is everyone_s problem. A committee comprising of reps from Towns & regional gov_t bodies should coordinate solutions.

If I could turn back time.... I would advise policy makers that nitrogen will become a problem and they could make the Cape more prosperous for their grandchildren by addressing it early. Build the structure for sewerage as they are developing downtown areas. Require septic systems that reduce nitrogen. Implement tax incentives to save water and reduce wastewater - e.g., tax credits for composting toilets. Establish bylaws that require water conservation. Implement a certification program with incentives for homeowners that zeroscape their lawns.

It's a gull... no, it's a glider... no, it's Super N! "Super N, the Nitrogen Neutralizer" is the Cape's new super hero. Super N is an engineer and inventor extraordinaire, who would design a cost effective and efficient nitrogen-eliminating septic system that could be installed immediately an houses for whom no sewer hookup is practical. Super N would also design for a new, cost effective nitrogen-eliminating wastewater treatment plant that could be built in communities where population density is high enough to make that solution practical. Recognizing the value of natural systems, Super N would identify areas where natural solutions such as wetlands and stormewater runoff basins could be enhanced. Finally, Super N would contribute all the royalties from the patents on the nitrogen removing wastewater systems to a fund that offsets the costs of such systems.

Funding the town's wastewater plan is critical to the community's economic well being and growth. Without clean water, the town won't be able to attract visitors and tourist revenue is a key income stream. Also without clean water, the town won't be able to attract new business or new residents, both of which form the tax base we need to grow. Ultimately, without addressing the wastewater issue the town will lose residents, lose visitors, and lose tourists. While the cost of implementing the town's wastewater plan is expensive, the cost of not doing so is even more so.

Share the costs, but discount based on income\nWhile some of the over 65 population is on a fixed income, others are able to pay. Similarly, some of the under 65 population have limited incomes and may not be able to pay more in taxes. A cost share is appropriate as we are all part of the problem, and discounting for income would address those who - regardless of age - can't pay more.

Yes, it would be fair to charge summer visitors to help pay for the Cape's water infrastructure. Everyone benefits from clean drinking water, including summer visitors. Everyone poops, including summer visitors. That said, while the total contribution to the problem by summer visitors is significant, the individual contribution of each visitor is less than that of a year round resident. Therefore, the burden of payment shouldn't be placed entirely on summer visitors. As far as how such a payment system should be implemented, that's harder. A room tax could work. A flush tax could work and could be addressed at everyone.

Expansion of Bottle Bill, State or Federal Grants, Gaming Proceeds\nFirst, it is critical to get state and federal government support. Cape Cod is a resource for all of Massachusetts, and brings in a significant amount of revenue to the state. As such, state resources should be part of the solution. Likewise, Cape Cod is a national resource and federal resources should also be part of the solution.Second, I like the idea of expanding the bottle bill. This could have the added benefit of encouraging recycling and reducing plastic waste.Third, as gaming revenue represents a new stream not yet budgeted or earmarked, this would be a good place to turn to for funds.

On a personal level, I can contribute to the Cape's economic health by buying local and supporting local businesses whenever possible. I can further contribute by doing my part to improve the environment, including taking steps to reduce my contribution to the problem of excess nitrogen.On a professional level, my organization - the National Marine Life Center - can continue and increase 1) our contribution to the Cape's natural heritage through rehabilitating stranded marine life, 2) our contribution to the Cape's knowledge economy through scientific research, 3) our contribution to the Cape's educational economy by providing inquiry-based, hands-on, STEM educational programs that supplement what is offered in the schools, 4) our further contribution to the Cape's educational economy by providing hands-on, experiential learning opportunities to older students through internships, work study programs, and service learning projects, and 5) our contribution to the revitalization of Main Street, Bourne.

Currently, the most important slices of the economy for the Cape appear to be Retail Trade, Healthcare and Social Assistance, and Accommodation and Food Service. While these are currently the largest pieces of the pie (or pizza), some of the other slices of the economy hold promise in creating a more sustainable and prosperous community. Increasing the Professional and Technical Services slice would bring more well-paid, year-round workers and their families to the Cape. Increasing the Information slice, now possible with Open Cape, could likewise bring year-round, low impact workers to the Cape.
The primary source that affects the Cape's nitrogen levels is septic systems. Additional sources include fertilizer, dishwashers, garbage disposals, and stormwater runoff.

Sea Birds\nI can't actually choose just one organism. All listed (and more) are integral to the allure of the Cape Cod environment and the strength of its economy. We are all interconnected and we must address the Cape's wastewater problem - for the plants and animals, the people, and the ecosystem.

Once upon a Cape, a family brought in a backhoe to landscape their lawn, then planted it and applied a bag of fertilizer. Excess nutrients from the fertilizer mixed with those from their septic system, ran off into the water and caused an algae bloom which deprived the native eelgrass of light and making it die back, and which then robbed the water of oxygen as it decayed thus causing the fish to die or swim away. The family played Cape-2-O and learned about water quality and the problem of excess nutrients, then worked with a local shellfisherman to establish an oyster aquaculture project in their bay which would eventually help clean the water.

C\nDefinitely a Cape Cod yard! I haven't used any fertilizer for several years so my estimate is 0. I used to occasionally use an organic fertilizer/weed controller combo product, but after playing this game I won't be doing that anymore!!

response: Wastewater\nHopefully this is not wishful thinking. Wastewater is the biggest contributor to the Cape's nutrient problem, solutions are available, we HAVE to be able to control this! Many people expressed willingness to reduce or eliminate fertilizer application as a direct, personal action they can take while reducing nitrogen in wastewater requires a lot more work. But with educational tools like this game and with a lot of smart people focusing on the problem we CAN solve this!
